entry.content: ç”¨åå‘ä¼ æ’­ç®—æ³•æ›´æ–°æƒé‡çš„ç®—æ³•å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š ç»™æ¯ä¸€å±‚çš„æƒé‡èµ‹å€¼ä¸º 0 è¾“å…¥å±‚â†’éšå±‚çš„æƒé‡ $\Delta w_{ij}=0$ éšå±‚â†’è¾“å‡ºå±‚çš„æƒé‡ $\Delta W_j=0$â€‹ å¯¹è®­ç»ƒé›†é‡Œçš„æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°æ®ï¼š ä½¿ç”¨ forward passï¼Œè®¡ç®—è¾“å‡ºèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„å€¼ $\hat y$ è®¡ç®—è¾“å‡ºèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„è¯¯å·®æ¢¯åº¦ $\delta^o=(y-\hat y)fâ€™(z)$ï¼Œ è¿™é‡Œçš„ $z=\sum_jW_ja_j$ å°†è¯¯å·®åå‘ä¼ é€’åˆ°éšå±‚ $\delta^h_j=\delta^oW_jfâ€™(h_j)$ æ›´æ–°æƒé‡æ­¥é•¿ $\Delta W_j = \Delta W_j + \delta^oa_j$ $\Delta w{ij} = \Delta w{ij} + \delta^h_ja_i$ æ›´æ–°æƒé‡ï¼ˆÎ· ä¸ºå­¦ä¹ ç‡ï¼Œm ä¸ºè¾“å…¥èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„ä¸ªæ•°): $W_j = W_j + \eta \Delta W_j /m$ $w{ij} = w{ij} + \eta \Delta w_{ij} /m$ é‡å¤ e æ¬¡è®­ç»ƒæ­¥éª¤ (epochs) åœ¨ python ä¸­å®ç°å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344454647484950515253545556575859606162636465666768697071727374757677787980import numpy as npfrom data_prep import features, targets, features_test, targets_testnp.random.seed(21)def sigmoid(x): """ Calculate sigmoid """ return 1 / (1 + np.exp(-x))# Hyperparametersn_hidden = 2 # number of hidden unitsepochs = 900learnrate = 0.005n_records, n_features = features.shapelast_loss = None# Initialize weightsweights_input_hidden = np.random.normal(scale=1 / n_features ** .5, size=(n_features, n_hidden))weights_hidden_output = np.random.normal(scale=1 / n_features ** .5, size=n_hidden)for e in range(epochs): del_w_input_hidden = np.zeros(weights_input_hidden.shape) del_w_hidden_output = np.zeros(weights_hidden_output.shape) for x, y in zip(features.values, targets): ## Forward pass ## # Calculate the output hidden_input = np.dot(x, weights_input_hidden) # xÂ·w hidden_output = sigmoid(hidden_input) output = sigmoid(np.dot(hidden_output, weights_hidden_output)) ## Backward pass ## # Calculate the network's prediction error error = y - output # Calculate error term for the output unit output_error_term = error * output * (1 - output) ## propagate errors to hidden layer # Calculate the hidden layer's contribution to the error hidden_error = np.dot(output_error_term, weights_hidden_output) # Calculate the error term for the hidden layer hidden_error_term = hidden_error * hidden_output * (1 - hidden_output) # Update the change in weights del_w_hidden_output += output_error_term * hidden_output del_w_input_hidden += hidden_error_term * x[:,None] # x.T # Update weights weights_input_hidden += learnrate * del_w_input_hidden / n_records weights_hidden_output += learnrate * del_w_hidden_output / n_records # Printing out the mean square error on the training set if e % (epochs / 10) == 0: hidden_output = sigmoid(np.dot(x, weights_input_hidden)) out = sigmoid(np.dot(hidden_output, weights_hidden_output)) loss = np.mean((out - targets) ** 2) if last_loss and last_loss < loss: print("Train loss: ", loss, " WARNING - Loss Increasing") else: print("Train loss: ", loss) last_loss = loss# Calculate accuracy on test datahidden = sigmoid(np.dot(features_test, weights_input_hidden))out = sigmoid(np.dot(hidden, weights_hidden_output))predictions = out > 0.5accuracy = np.mean(predictions == targets_test)print("Prediction accuracy: {:.3f}".format(accuracy)) ä½ å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ„Ÿå…´è¶£ï¼š DeepLearningç¬”è®°ï¼šBackpropagation åå‘ä¼ æ’­ç®—æ³• DeepLearningç¬”è®°ï¼šå¤šèŠ‚ç‚¹ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œ DLç¬”è®°ï¼šç”¨ python å®ç°æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™çš„ç®—æ³• DLç¬”è®°ï¼šæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™ Gradient Descent DLç¬”è®°ï¼šCost function æŸå¤±å‡½æ•° DLç¬”è®°ï¼šActivation Function æ¿€æ´»å‡½æ•° DLç¬”è®°ï¼šLinear regression çº¿æ€§å›å½’ DLç¬”è®°ï¼šNeural Networks ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œ DLç¬”è®°ï¼šæœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ å’Œæ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ çš„åŒºåˆ«

This project was made for fab academy 2016 final project. Most of code are based on open source software and I have no plan for commerciallise. I see it less as a product but more as an open source project, people who like music or have some idea about theremin can play, share ideas, code. Maybe it can help school kids to learn sensor and frequency of notes. They could learn ultra-sonic sensor working by detecting distance between objects. entry.title: Reading notes â€“ Asking the right questions[2]
entry.content: Part 1 Chapter 2 What Are the Issue and the Conclusion? â€œBefore we evaluate someoneâ€™s reasoning, we must first find it.â€ Similarly, before we solve a problem, we must distinguish it. â€œAn issue is a question or controversy responsible for the conversation or discussion. It is the stimulus for what is being said.â€ Kinds of IssuesDescriptive Issues: â€œDescriptive issues are those that raise questions about the accuracy of descriptions of the past, present, or future.â€ ã€Informativeã€‘ Prescriptive Issues: â€œPrescriptive issues are those that raise questions about what we should do or what is right or wrong, good or bad.â€ ã€ä»·å€¼åˆ¤æ–­ã€‘ Searching for the issue self explicit Ask yourself â€œWhatâ€™s the topic the author trying to argueâ€ The conclusion is the message that the speaker or writer wishes you to accept. Searching for the Authorsâ€™s or Speakerâ€™s Conclusionâ€œWhatâ€™s the writer or speaker trying to prove?â€ â€œConclusions are inferred; they are derived from reasoning.â€ nothing Claims â€”â€”-> opinions Claims â€”â€”-> conclusions reasoning proves How to find the conclusion: Ask what the issue is. Look for indicator words. Look in likely locations. Remember what a conclusion is not. Check the context of the communication and the authorâ€™s background. Ask â€œand therefore?â€â€œBefore you can evaluate an authorâ€™s argument, you must clearly identify the issue and conclusion.â€ Once find the conclusion, your concern is: â€œShould I accept that conclusion on the basis of what is supporting the claim?â€ CHAPTER 3 What Are the Reasons?Reasons are beliefs, evidence, metaphors, analogies, and other statements offered to support of justify conclusions. Reasons are explanations or rationales. You cannot determine the worth of a conclusion until you identify the reasons. ã€Identifying reasons requires us to remain open and curious.ã€‘ Reasons+Conclusion=ArgumentArguments: intent to convince, different quality. Reasons are the tool by which conclusions are shaped and modified. Initiating the Questioning ProcessApproach the argument with a questioning attitude. Ask question with â€œwhyâ€. ã€After you identifying a conclusion, try to play the role of the communicator. Ask questions like â€œWhy am I support or disagree?â€ã€‘ Kinds of ReasonsBy evidence, we mean specific information that someone uses to furnish â€œproofâ€ for something. Evidence includes facts, research finding, examples from real life, statistics, appeals to experts and authorities, personal testimonials, metaphors, and analogies. Keeping the Reasons and Conclusions StraightClues for Identifying and Organizing the Reasoning of a Passage Circle indicator words. Underline the reasons and conclusion in different colors of ink, or highlight the conclusion and underline the reasons. Label the reasons and conclusion in the margin. After reading long passages, make a list of reasons at the end of the essay. CHAPTER 4 What Words Or Phrases Are Ambiguous?Whenever you are reading or listening, force yourself to search for ambiguity. Locating Key Terms and PhrasesAmbiguity refers to the existence of multiple possible meanings for a word or phrase. Summary of Clues for Locating Key Terms Review the issue for possible key terms. Look for crucial words or phrases within the reasons and conclusion. Keep an eye out for abstract words and phrases. Use reverse role-playing to determine how someone might define certain words and phrases differently. ã€First, find terms that may have more than one plausible meaning. Then identify words or phrases that seem crucial in the reasoning structure.ã€‘ The more abstract a word or phrase, the more likely it is to be susceptible to multiple interpretations. ã€Pay attention to â€œnewâ€ concepts. Ask this question as often as possible: what other meanings may it be? ã€‘ Determining AmbiguityOnly the ambiguity in the reasoning is crucial to critical thinkers. ã€Tips: Can I create a mental picture(maybe specifically), based on what these phrases represent?ã€‘ Ambiguity, Definitions, and the DictionaryMeanings usually come in one of three forms: synonyms, examples, and specific criteria. Synonyms and examples are inadequate when evaluating most controversial issues. SummaryYou cannot evaluate an essay until you know the communicatorâ€™s intended meaning of key terms and phrases as well as alternative meanings they could conceivably have had in the context of the argument. â€œWhat could be meant?â€ â€œWhat is meant by the key terms?â€ Four very important components of the reasoning: the key terms and phrases; which of these are adequately defined; which of these possess other possible definitions, which if substituted, would modify your reaction to the reasoning; and which of these are ambiguous within the context of the argument.

entry.title: Reading notes - Asking the right questions[1]
entry.content: Asking the Right Questionsâ€”â€”A Guide to Critical Thinking (8th Edition) The benefit of asking the right question: reasoningï¼ˆæ¨ç†ï¼‰,critical thinkingï¼ˆæ€è¾¨ï¼‰,judgementï¼ˆåˆ¤æ–­ï¼‰,decision makingï¼ˆå†³ç­–ï¼‰. To give you the framework, method and steps to solve a problem. CHAPTER 1 The Benefit of Asking the Right Questions â€œOpinions are cheap; anyone can have one of those.â€ True enough. If we can not tell important opinion from nonsense, that the opinion weâ€™ve made might be rubbish as well. so â€œYou need to build skills and attitudes that will enable you to decide for yourself which opinions to make your own.â€ Yeah,we all have two choices, one is to ask and the other is to ignore everything. One is laborious and the other is convenient. It all depends. Critical Thinking to the RescueGoal: use critical questions to identify the best decision available. â€œA system of questions is more consistent with the spirit of curiosity, wonder, and intellectual adventure essential to critical thinking. â€œ â€œCritical questions provide a stimulus and direction for critical thinking.â€ Canâ€™t agree more. Asking a question is always the first step of solving a problem. Why? I didnâ€™t have a clear thought about it, now the keyword â€œstimulusâ€ and â€œdirectionâ€ give me a clue. Another question, how? Keep your curiosity. Critical thinking refers to the following: 1. awareness of a set of interrelated critical questions; 2. ability to ask and answer critical questions at appropriate times; and the 3. desire to actively use the critical questions.â€There are two points that I feel hard to achieve. 1. ability to answer critical questions; 2. at appropriate times(æ—¶æœŸ). Keep them. The Sponge and Panning for Gold: Alternative Thinking StylesSponge approach(knowledge acquisition): Absorb everything. Interactive approach(active interaction with knowledge as it is being acquired): Take the question asking attitude. â€œSuch a thinking style requires active participation. The writer is trying to speak to you, and you should try to talk back to him.â€ â€œto ask frequent questions and to reflect on the answers. â€œ Note that these two approaches are complementary. The example of sponge reader is just another me: â€œHe memorizes the reasoning, but doesnâ€™t evaluate it.â€Well, lots of efforts should be paid before becoming a Panning for Gold. 1. Why did he say so? 2. Are there any questions? 3. What about his answers? 4. My conclusions? Remember, the better approach is interactive involvement. Let yourself be involved! Be a active reader and listener by asking questions. Weak-Sense and Strong-Sense Critical Thinking Weak-sense critical thinking is the use of critical thinking to defend your current beliefs. Strong-sense critical thinking is the use of the same skills to evaluate all claims and beliefs, especially your own. We make decisions based on our â€œhistoryâ€. When listen to others, put them on a shelf. That is to say, keep openness and leave your emotion temporary. Be willing to change your mind. The interplay between out old answers and new ones provides a basis for our growth.
